doc.field: Solana's visit in Bonn

NATO Secretary General Solana is meeting with Chancellor Schroeder in Bonn for an exchange of views. One of the topics deals with the crisis in Kosovo. Solana threatened the parties to the conflict again with military actions. If Serbs and Kosovo-Albanians would not meet for negotiations, Nato would intervene. Chancellor Schroeder assured Solana total support. Later on, Solana talked with Minister of Defense Scharping and Foreign Minister Fischer. Germany had agreed to participate in a military action on the Balkan, if necessary, in order to force peace negotiations. NATO confirmed again its willingness for an intervention in front of the Balkan contact group, to which the Federal Republic belongs, a few days before the ultimatum expired.
Soldiers receive special training for mission in Kosovo

German soldiers who may be ordered to serve in the mission in Kosovo are now to receive special training, as announced by a spokesperson for the Ministry of Defense. Soldiers will be learning how to free unarmed observers if they have been taken prsioners by a warfaring group. A total of 800 soldiers will be trained to be ready for deployment in 4-5 weeks.
Warning strikes of metal workers in northern Germany

IG Metall (Union for Metal, Engineering and Electronics) continued its warning strikes parallel to the third collective bargaining round for the metal induxtry in northern Germany. Several thousand employees of the Ford plant in Cologne alone walked out. Most of the plant was brought to a standstill. The head of the negotiations for IG Metall for the coastal district, Teichmueller, demanded on NDR a better offer from the regional employers in Bremen. They, in turn, asked for actions from the union. The talks in Bremen for the north German metal workers were postponed without any results until February 9.
PDS does not have to compensate victims of the SED regime

According to a judgment of the Federal High Court, the PDS does not have to pay compensation to the victims of the SED regime, and it does not have to financially compensate those who had wrongfully been imprisoned. The judges in Karlsruhe issued their final rejection of the complaint filed by a former GDR citizen against the SED successor party.
Axa Colonia intends to take over Albingia

The Axa Colonia Group intends to take over the majority in the Hamburg-based insurance company Albingia and move up to become Germany's second largest property insurance company. The French group offered more than 1.6 billion DM for an 84% share of the joint stock. The company announced in Cologne that the planned acquisition depends on whether the parent company GRE will accept the takeover offer by the Axa company Sun Life. The competent anti-trust offices still have to approve the merger. Axa intends to conclude the merger by the end of May 1999.
Number of AIDS infected persons in Germany reaches highest

At the end of December, 37,000 persons in Germany were HIV positive. According to figures from the Robert Koch Institute, this number has never been this high since the discovery of the virus. Every year, approximately 2000 persons are infected with the virus in Germany. In the same time period, the number of persons contracting AIDS went down. The researchers reported that 800 persons contracted AIDS last year, while 800 persons died from AIDS. These numbers are the lowest over the last ten years. The higher number of infections, yet lower number of contractions appears to be the result of new treatment methods. Since therapies exist which use a combination of treatment substances, doctors are able to further delay the outbreak of the disease.
German researcher discovers origin of HIV virus

A German researcher and her team succeeded in determing the genetic origin of the HIV1 viruses. The researchers determined through a comparison of genetic make-up that they are coming from a west-African breed of chimpanzees. They also pointed out that this breed of chimpanzees is immune to the virus. Researchers now hope for new treatment methods.
Second missing person found dead after avalanche

One day after the avalanche accident in the Chiemgau Alps, the second missing person was recovered dead. It is assumed that the man was the companion of the woman from Upper Bavaria who had been recovered dead yesterday. At some time, 180 persons participated in the search at the site of the accident.
Cologne's main railway station closed for hours after bomb threat

The main railway station in Cologne was closed to all railway traffic in the afternoon following a bomb threat. The bomb was not found, but the main railway station has been opened again. An anonymous caller had informed a fire station that a bomb would explode in the main railway station within two minutes. Although nothing happened, the main railway station in Cologne was closed and search dogs were brought in. Since they could not uncover anything, the "all-clear" signal was sounded at 5 p.m. In the meantime, thousands of travellers had to wait outside. Since Cologne is one of the major railway traffic junctions in Europe, travellers to and from Cologne will have to anticipate major delays until 10 p.m., officials from the Bahn AG announced.
Tourists injured in bus accident in Egypt
31 German tourists were injured in a bus accident, some of them suffered serious injuries. The travellers come from Baden-Wuerttemberg and Rhineland-Palatinate.
German Army tank runs over 51-year-old man during a field exercise

A 51-year-old German civil servant of the US Army was run over and killed by a 60 ton tank of the German Army. The accident occurred during a field exercise on the training area Hohenfels located in the Upper Palatinate.
